title.narrative: Short term study on the evidence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV).

description.narrative: This study will review the potential threat to humans from Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV). It will review and summarise knowledge about MERS-CoV and its threat to humans in the region and provide recommendations on evidence gaps and on how to address them as a precautionary principle. This review will also look into any on-going research (where identified) to assess the prevalence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) in African camel populations and the epidemiology of the disease in African camels to ascertain how and if the viruses has spread from camels to humans.

title.narrative: The EdTech Hub (Educational Technology Hub) - Robust research and innovation on digital, data and technology in education systems, providing global public research goods and direct country support for effective decision making on edtech.

description.narrative: The Ed Tech Hub's mission is to achieve 70 years of business as usual progress in developing world education by 2030 through effective use of digital in education systems. This includes the use of digital, data and technology in schools, in ministries and at home to improve learning, efficiency and value for money. It currently provides innovative support, research on learning outcomes, direct support for governments and global leadership that the sector really needs. As a response to Covid-19, the Hub has pivoted its focus to reaching the 1.5 billion children out of school, convening and curating rapid evidence and advice for policy makers to use in this time of distance learning. DFID, the Gates Foundation and the World Bank are the donors for this programme. The EdTech Hub directly contributes to the manifesto commitment on girls' education.

title.narrative: Supporting preparedness, mitigation and response to the primary and secondary impacts of COVID-19 on IDP and vulnerable populations in Yemen

description.narrative: Given the context of COVID-19, combined with the already dire humanitarian needs in Yemen, our approach aims to prevent, mitigate and respond to COVID-19 in the immediate/short-term, by providing life-saving assistance through targeted and coordinated activities in health, nutrition, WASH, protection, and cash to IDP and vulnerable populations. The programme will provide an integrated, multi-partner package across three governorates (Abyan, Lahj, and Shabwah), as well as within Azurrah district in Hodeidah, and limited activities targeting highly vulnerable IDP populations in Taizz.

reporting-org.narrative: The Leprosy Mission England and Wales

title.narrative: Fueling Opportunities to end Unemployment for Nepalis with Disabilities

description.narrative:
1. Unemployed disabled people aged 18-45 years with academic qualifications 2. Unemployed disabled people aged 18-45 years with vocational qualifications 3. Unemployed disabled people aged 18-45 years with no qualifications 4. Those aged 18-60 who are currently carers for unemployed disabled people.
COVID-19 Rapid Response project: 1. Medical staff at Anandaban Hospital will be trained to respond to COVID-19. 2. Local community residents and people affected by leprosy showing symptoms will be tested for COVID-19 and positive cases will receive critical care. 3. Households in the 5 targeted districts, particularly those affected by leprosy and disability, will receive emergency food and sanitation packages.

FOUND will support 2,500 unemployed skilled people with disabilities, from five economic hub districts of Nepal, to find and thrive in formal or self-employment. Targeting 875 business owners and employers, it will improve knowledge, confidence, skills and attitudes so they understand the abilities of people with disabilities. For people with disabilities it will improve employability skills and self-confidence, pilot inclusive job search and hiring practices and collate evidence of what works.
COVID-19 Rapid Response project: This project aims to improve the preparedness of Anandaban Hospital, Nepal to provide a COVID-19 response to the local community. This response will comprise of a fully equipped and staffed isolation ward at the hospital where COVID-19 patients can be treated by trained staff. In addition, emergency humanitarian assistance will be provided to households living within 5 districts, identified during an assessment carried out in spring 2020.

Outcome: A total of 2,500 unemployed disabled people living in economic hub districts of Morang, Lalitpur, Kathmandu, Kapilbastu and Rupandehi in Nepal, secure and sustain formal or self-employment for at least 12 months. Output 1: Improved processes for disabled people's job search, entry, and survival in formal or self-employment Output 2: Improved employability skills and self-confidence of unemployed disabled people Output 3: Increased business owners' and employers' confidence in employing disabled people Output 4: Improved evidence of what works in supporting disabled people to enter and thrive in formal and self-employment in Nepal.
COVID-19 Rapid Response project: Objective 1: Leprosy health workers and Anandaban Leprosy Referral Hospital are well-trained, supplied and equipped to manage COVID-19 and to protect themselves from COVID-19 infection. Objective 2: Leprosy-affected communities have the life-saving information they need to protect themselves and others from corona virus infection. Objective 3: Leprosy affected communities access vital sanitation and food packages required to protect themselves from infection.

Here in the UK we’ve all had to make sacrifices to protect each other and save lives during the coronavirus pandemic, and witnessed the incredible dedication of our amazing NHS staff.
But as we struggle with the virus at home, people around the world need our help – families who have fled violence, conflict and hunger in countries where there is no NHS if they fall ill.
Many are now living in crowded refugee and displacement camps with little access to medical care, clean water or enough food, making them extremely vulnerable to coronavirus. In these places, the virus is likely to be even more deadly than it has been here.
Imagine having to leave everything behind to keep your family safe, only to face a deadly new threat: Covid-19. This is the reality for people living in tents and makeshift shelters without running water or soap in places like Syria, Yemen and Somalia.
But, as we have seen in the UK, simple measures can make a huge difference. If we act now to protect millions of vulnerable refugees and displaced people, many lives can be saved.
We need your help to:
provide families with clean water, soap and information on keeping themselves safe provide frontline medical and aid workers with equipment and supplies to care for the vulnerable and sick ensure families get enough food to prevent malnutrition, particularly amongst children People who have already suffered so much need your help now more than ever to face this new threat. Please give whatever you can at this challenging time for us all.

title.narrative: Geoff Herrington Foundation: Response to COVID-19

description.narrative:
Through this holistic COVID-19 response, we aim to achieve the following: 1. Vulnerable children and their families have increased awareness on COVID-19 and best practices to limit its spread.
2. Vulnerable children and their families have access to critical support and protection services through child helplines, case management, unstructured psychosocial support and referral services.
3. Protection risks of vulnerable people reduced through provision of individual protection assistance 4. Increased capacity for service delivery of the Child Helpline

title.narrative: Take Two - War Child UK Response to COVID-19 in Afghanistan

description.narrative: Provision of individual protection assistance (multi-purpose cash grant) targeting extremely vulnerable households who lost their livelihoods, returnees from Iran, victims of protection incidents (cases referred to and followed by the case management team). The IPA will be considered to address specific needs of people affected by the COVID-19 emergency. A total of 380 households selected from Herat and Badghis provinces based on their level of vulnerability due to COVID-19 will benefit from provision of IPA. The project will be complementary to WCUK existing project in Herat and Badghis where assistance is provided to Unaccompanied Minors (UAMs) crossing the border from Iran. UAMs are provided with Child Protection services and reunified with their families. As support under this project ends after reunification, this project will fill this gap and provide much needed additional assistance for children and their families who have experience significant loss of livelihoods and struggle with many new challenges due to COVID-19, to help them to cope with the impact of the crisis, preventing adoption of negative copying mechanisms and reduce risk of getting infected by the virus. Criteria for the selection of most vulnerable groups who will benefit from IPA will include households who are female headed, child headed households and those households who lost their income due to COVID-19 crisis who were previously engaged in informal or daily labour works. The grant will also support households in Herat and Badghis through provision of Covid-19 hyginen kits for 380 household with families of 7 members which means 2800 househld memebrs will benfit from the project (based on the WASH Cluster recommendations). The kit include bathing soap, Laundery Soap, plastic soap case, plastic jerry can (rigid 10liter, 2 liter ewer, cotex/sanitary pad).

title.narrative: Stanley Thomas Jonhnson Foundation: UNICEF Ndele Annual Top-Up + COVID-19 Adaptation

description.narrative: - Annual top-up (second year out of three) from the Stanley Thomas Johnson Foundation to complement the UNICEF-funded grant in Ndele which ended on 31 July; - Top-up received from the Stanley Thomas Johnson Foundation to cover (retroactively as necessary) COVID-19 adaptation costs of the UNICEF project in Ndele.

title.narrative: OCHA: Strengthening the Protection of the Most Vulnerable Children and Families in the Context of COVID-19 Prevention and Child Protection Issues in Ndele

description.narrative:
The project aims to strengthen the capacities of community structures to prevent COVID-19, as well as violence against the most vulnerable children in Ndele, CAR. It aims to save lives and reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19 in vulnerable communities.
The project focuses on 2 main components: 1) Community capacity building to protect children and prevent and reduce the impact of the spread of COVID-19 on communities; 2) Direct or remote psychosocial response, as well as holistic assistance (psychosocial support, referral and socio-economic assistance) to survivors of GBV and families at risk of violence.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

title.narrative: OCHA: Providing Suitable Protection Services to Children, Young People and their Parents During the COVID-19 Response in Goma and Kinshasa

description.narrative: This project is part of the activities related to the response against COVID-19 in the DRC. It aims to support efforts to contain the spread of the pandemic by providing children, young people and their parents with credible information on prevention and response to COVID-19 through two free hotlines: the number 116 which covers Kinshasa and its surroundings, and the number 117 which covers the city of Goma. Thanks to these two assistance lines, the social workers of the DUAS and the DIVAS are supported for the identification, referral and management of child protection and SGBV cases in the areas affected by the pandemic. The project also aims to reach the most vulnerable categories of children in urban areas, namely street children and children in conflict with the law, with awareness-raising messages and hygiene and personal protection kits. Finally, children and parents particularly affected by COVID-19 are provided with flexible cash assistance to prevent or respond to child protection or protection needs such as access to care, transport assistance, legal assistance, temporary accommodation, quarantine / containment, and food.
Awareness raising, hygiene kits distribution and cleaning campaigns in IDP camps in Taiz

title.narrative: Take Two - Integrated Food security and Livelihoods and Child Protection assistance to support COVID-19 affected populations

description.narrative: An integrated FSL and CP Project will be implemented in Bani Husaish, Sanaa Governorate to assist children and families affected by COVID-19, including IDPs who are among the most vulnerable groups in the context of the pandemic. WCUK will assist 488 new IDPs Households (HHs) through provision of unconditional cash assistance covering the Minimum Food Basket (MFB) and will further provide cash for protection assistance to 112 identified vulnerable cases. Finally, WCUK will provide legal documentation support to IDPs communities. Due to the conflict in Yemen and the crisis most of the IDPs do not have legal documents, as they either lost them or left them behind in their houses. Children need birth certificates to be able to join schools and get further help from other organizations. Parents need IDs as well to be able to receive any type of help such as cash and food baskets, etc. WC UK will assist IDPs without documentation and referring them to appropriate authorities. These documents will include issuing birth certificates for children and IDs for adults (+18).

title.narrative: Learning for All: Inclusive education for learners with complex disabilities in Kenya (plus Rapid Response programme)

description.narrative:
300 children with complex disabilities in 6 Counties of Kenya have improved learning outcomes through accessing quality inclusive education and the Government of Kenya is committed to developing a framework for providing Learning Support Assistants (LSAs) in mainstream schools for all learners with complex disabilities in line with the Education Sector Policy for Learners and Trainees with Disabilities (2018).
In addition, alongside this a Rapid Response programme was delivered over six months from September 2020 called "COVID-19 rapid response for people with deafblindness, their families and schools in Kenya." This focused on urgent priorities in response to the impact of COVID-19, with activities including accessible handwashing stations at 25 schools, providing accessible information on COVID-19, food and medicine packages for the most vulnerable and psycho-social support counselling for families of persons with complex disabilities.

activity-date.narrative: The project implementation period is from 15.07.2019 to 14.07.2022 (36 months)

title.narrative: Support Ministry of Health Preparedness to Respond to COVID-19

description.narrative: Activity 1- International Medical Corps will set up screening room for triage and isolation of patients at the hospitals in Bria, Bambari and Birao. screening and isolation units installed. No patients tested positive during the reporting period. last positive case was in Bria in June 2020. Activity 2: Ensure case management through a 20-bed establishment in the hospitals of Bria, Bambari and Birao. Installation of tents with 20 beds in Bria and 8 beds in Birao. Activity 3: Purchase and supply pharmaceutical products, medical supplies, including PPE, medical equipment and IPC supplies for the three hospitals of Bria, Bambari and Birao and MSF France. international order for drugs, supplies and medical equipment launched in September and in November 2020.This was due to the fact that after the project was approved no cases were recorded in the country therefore IMC was considering modifying the requests according to the situation on the ground. Part of this order will be a donation to MSF-France in Bria. Activity 4: Provide MHPSS services to staff, patients and community members, including telephone counseling, Psychosocial support to frontline workers, patients and their families. MHPSs team were available to offer services to patients who have been screened. Activity 5: Strengthen the installation of additional hand washing stations in the health establishment and waste management (according to the COVID-19 protocol). Each isolation site is equipped with safe environmental hygiene measures. Activity 6: Recruit human resources for the project. IMC launched recruitment of staff for the project, but delayed due to shortage of health care personnel like Medical doctors. Activity 7: Transport of supplies to the field. PPE received in country was transported in September 2020. Output 2 - Activity 1: International Medical Corps UK will use the existing Community Health Workers (CHWs) to conduct community and household level awareness on COVID-19 such as dispelling myths, and communication on preventive measures, symptoms and what to do if ill. CHWs were trained and provided with masks for door-to-door visits to protect them. IEC materials on COVID-19 messages were distributed to them to raise awareness and emphasize to recognize the symptoms of COVID-19. Activity 2: Involve CHWs to conduct community-based surveillance and patients’ referral’s, Weekly report, is shared during the meeting of the multisectoral prefectural committee responsible for locally coordinating the response to COVID 19 in each site before being sent to the MOH.

title.narrative: Transformational Training for Kindergarten Teachers in the Eastern Region of Ghana TTT-ER

description.narrative: This three-year project aims to enable 933 teachers and 600 student teachers in Ghana’s Eastern Region to deliver the Ghana Education Service kindergarten curriculum through an active, play-based pedagogy which will improve learning outcomes for 38,512 kindergarten pupils. Head teachers, College of Education lecturers and Ghana Education Service officers will be able to deliver training and monitor and sustain the quality classroom practice and parents will be sensitized to the importance of early years education.

title.narrative: Communities at the Centre: Enabling First Line Emergency Responses in Myanmar

description.narrative: Protracted conflicts require a new, women-led approach to shift power to local populations so they can move from short-term humanitarian ways of working to integrated approaches involving localisation, capacity building, humanitarian interventions, development and security, with the aim to leave no one behind. This action is designed to equip local civil society organisations (CSOs) and community-based front-line emergency actors and self-help groups (CBOs) with the resources to prepare and respond to crises. In the Mrauk-U and Buthidaung townships of Rakhine State, this action will enable local communities to design responsible, adaptable and accountable responses to crises – community- and women-led responses as dynamic and incisive as the conflict-induced crises and natural disasters are destabilising and unpredictable. This unpredictabulity is compunded by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic which will further affect the access to services and communities. This action has three components: 1) Local actors’ skills, capacities and knowledge are enhanced to lead responsibly managed, women-led first-line emergency responses; 2) Township contingency and response plans based on locally-led risk analysis established; and 3) Front Line Emer

This action has three components: 1) Local actors’ skills, capacities and knowledge are enhanced to lead responsibly managed, women-led first-line emergency responses; 2) Township contingency and response plans based on locally-led risk analysis established; and 3) Front Line Emergency Response system designed and implemented. Each component increases opportunities for local actors to lead the design and implementation of community- and women-led humanitarian mechanisms. In total, 33.114 IDPs and crisis-affected people, 50 key stakeholders (local authorities, private sector, religious entities, community groups) and 42 local organizations providing front line emergency responses in the targeted townships will benefit from this action: empowering communities, designing local responses, strengthening collective action and tackling power imbalances, thus laying the foundations for resilience against future crises.

title.narrative: Integrating Disability: Operationalisation of LNOB Approach

description.narrative: -Capacity building of CA, partners and stakeholders on better understanding of disablity issues, principles, legal instruments, existing status of service provision and inclusion within development programming -Support CA and partners to understand various tools and methodology for ensuring effective participation of peole with disabilities in CA development and disater prone programming - Technical support to CA on disability specific activities proposed in project in two pilot districts (Dhading and Rasuwa) -COVID-19 awareness messaging (Audio/Video Production and Broadcasting)

Through this project Christian Aid and partners are able to produce disability inclusion guidelines and rolled out,indcusion audit report is produced,the knowledge of staff is increased on disablity inclusion and two survey report is produced. COVID response:
-Increased inclusion of disability specific issues in the COVID-19 response activities of federal government, CA and its local Partners. -People with disabilities who are facing barriers in communication and information due to inaccessibility and often left behind on right to information are more informed and conscious on the COVID-19 precautionary measured through messaging and broadcasting.

title.narrative: Supporting Recovery,Protection & Livelihoods of the Marginalised,Displaced & Returnees-Nigeria AA

description.narrative: The activities are designed to reach the target population using a well-structured detailed and sequenced implementation plans that captures specific activities and timelines. In 7 days, stakeholders identification and engagement would have been concludeed with identification of CRM focal persons whiloe the rapid assessment to determine beneficiaries of NFIs and cash will be underway. The intervention will be led by local partners with already existing volunteer structures across communities who will serve as enumerators for rapid assessment and stakeholder engagement activities to be coordinated with government agencies, traditional institutions and faith based organizations that will be used for information communication and dissemination, risk communication and community engagement activities, distribution exercises and awareness creation, community and social mobilization officers will be adopted from the for mass awareness and sensitization activities at the community level.

The project will respond to WASH, Cash, Health, Protection and Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and NFIs. The response will reach beneficiaries experiencing health emergencies including Covid 19 and Yellow fever which are both WASH related emergencies to be addressed through an integrated risk communication and community engagements, local and mainstream approaches to WASH to maximize community participation and sustainability. Households and health facilities will be supported with Covid 19 WASH kits to strengthen infection prevention control (IPC) for Covid 19 to reduce community and facility transmission. WASH activities will mainstream yellow fever specifically with the provision of mosquito nets for households and facilities and also risk communication and community engagement activities including capacity building activities and Information Education and Communication (IEC) dissemination activities through local town criers for local reach and radio jingles for posters for wider reach. The project will train community volunteers who will track false information and myths at community levels and will urgently to address this false information using various channels such as door to door sensitisations and IEC materials

title.narrative: UTHAN- Uplifting the Poor and Needy

description.narrative:
- Improved understanding of vulnerability of individuals at the community and Municipality level. - Social Epowerment: # HHs are socially empowered through improved access to entitlements, services, social networks & meaningful participation in the development planning processes - Economic Empowerment: # of vulnerable individuals are directly economically empowered through improved income from diverse & appropriate climate smart agro based livelihood activities, off-farm activities & vocational trainings to fulfill their food & other basic needs - Safe Permanent shelter & CCA/DRR: # of vulnerable & earthquake affected individual are residing in safe permanent shelters & have effective representation in Ward & Municipality disaster preparedness processesand municipality have capacity & knowledge on climate induced disaster, its adaptation measures.
The key response activities of this project covers livelihood, food security, WASH/health & awareness as primary intervention. Distribution of food assistance/relief package, Installation of Hand washing station, PPE , disinfectant/ sanitizer, mask material support, special Food Package support for chronic disease patient & poorest people & radio PSAs are the major activities

The project will ensure that all 3416-vulnerable people are benefitted from activities, out of which 125 single women, 502 Older People, 289 PwDs, and 4065 extremely poor and food insecure people have improved awareness and access to their constitutional rights and entitlements and awared and prepared for future disaster and climate change
The response will ensure the food security of poor, people with disability, marginalized and vulnerable people through food assistance/relief package for at least 20-30 days, PPE, disinfectant, sanitizer, mask support for rural municipality will be done to secure health of medical person, FCHVs & person working in the front line, initiate some action for food production & livestock rearing which will help to recover from the covid-19 pandemic & ensure food security to some extent & broadcast 4 types of PSA from district local FMs will be aired to disseminate information on the virus.

title.narrative: Ensuring Food Security, Livelihood Support to the 2000 migrant families in Uttar Pradesh

description.narrative: Apart from livelihood support Dalit and marginalised community to be capacitated on rights and entitlements so they will be able to take raise voice with district administration. Also it is expected that the project will aim to reduce the migration along with gender discrimination and women participation will increase at village level activities. When the women generate income on her own, the gender based violence will also reduce and will give rise to social economic development of migrants particularly women.

The project will be implemented in 8 districts 60 gram panchayats of Uttar Pradesh targeting 2000 migrant families who have returned to their villages due to Covid 19 lockdown. These families have lost their livelihood in urban cities and their social economic status is very gloomy as of now. As per the Government guidelines these migrants will be provided work under NREGA along with job card and ration card. CASA will conduct a survey to assess the status of migrants with regard to social security documents and labour committee to be formed to monitor the rights & entitlements. CASA to provide dry ration consists of rice, wheatflour, oil, pulses and sanitary kits such as masks, soap and sanitary pads to last for 15 days to 2000 families. Some of the families have small agricultural land and to be provided seeds of millets, staple foods and vegetable seeds to enable them to grow on their own so that their food security will be ensured. Awareness programme on Covid 19 will also be conducted in these districts and distribution of IEC/BCC materials will be taken up.

title.narrative: Promoting Economic, Environment and social empowerment of vulnerable household (PRE-SERVE)

description.narrative:
The project intends to - Improved financial linkage and access - Improved Market System and entrepreneurship development - Improved agro-based livelihood and DRR/CCA
The COVID response activities intends to support the livelihood of vulnerable groups by providing essential food items as per the government's standard, provide WASH support to the community to ensure the hygiene and sanitation, support the quarantine spaces with blankets and water filters, distribution of PPE and medicine at ward and municipality level and disseminate information/awareness on COVID in the community to prevent the spread of the virus.

The proposed project “PRE-SERVE” aim to strengthen livelihood of vulnerable; through improving financial access, increase market linkage and making community resilient through climate adaptive livelihood options. This project designed to improve existing livelihood and initiate new livelihood activities through better financial access for vulnerable. Similarly, project envisioned to strengthen livelihood with establishing new market system & strengthening existing markets for their livelihood products.
-Food relief, tap bucket & soap distribution to 100 households daily wages workers, vulnerable households (single women, PWD, nearly/landless households, etc) per ward i.e., total of 500 households at the program are. -3 packets of sanitary pad for 50 adolescence girl at each ward -Distribution of hygienic food materials for pregnant & lactating mothers of 350 households - 4 types of awareness PSA total 20 times a day from 4 local radio stations & ICE dissemination at 30 location

title.narrative: Women's Empowerment For Engagement of Enterprenures on Livelihood (WE FEEL)

description.narrative:
This project intends to : - Increased access of rural population to resilient and innovative technology, technical information and skills for economic activities - Enhance participation and voice of traditionally excluded groups decision making through capacity development on inclusive planning, multi-stakeholder collaboration for addressing GBV and have effective representation in Ward and Municipality disaster preparedness processes
The COVID response activities intends to improve the food security of marginalized and most vulnerable HHs by providing food item support, circulate awareness on the virus and necessary precautions through IEC-posters, radio messages and programs and enhance the health and hygiene of community people by providing WASH support.

This project shall ensure that there is an increased knowledge and skills of target groups on resilient agriculture practices, and the market access ,Increase access of target groups on information related to off farm income opportunities, Increased awareness of excluded groups on their rights and participation in inclusive development planning and Disaster preparedness, Increased awareness and support system for addressing Gender Based Violence (GBV)
-Food support will be provided to 250 marginalised HHs i.e. daily wages labors, local farmers, Dalits, single women, elderly, disable etc. for 1 month during lockdown period. -3 PSA & 8 radio programme episode will be developed and broadcasted through local radio station on local language i.e. COVID -19 information, Hygiene Promotion & psychosocial/inclusion/GoN directives for 2 months -Disinfection equipment, Bucket with soap placed in community shops, health posts, ward office for prevention of COVID -19 spread in community.

title.narrative: PH R1: Strengthening Climate Advocacy in Asia in the time of COVID-19

description.narrative: For ACCC, within a year's time, we envision a regional civil society organization, along with its members, that is capable of ensuring the continuity of climate and disaster resilience advocacy, through innovate approaches, in government, inter-governmental, and relavant platforms in the face of COVID 19 and the new normal.

The project aims to : -strengthen capacities for climate advocacy in the time of COVID-19 where face to face engagement are no longer the norm in the short term. -support the work of ACCC members engaging in online advocacy through virtual roundtables, webinars and online campaigning. Specifically: 1)influencing the COVID 19 recovery/devt planning processes, the NDC and National adapt processes, with the purpose of strengthening movement-building, policy, and campaign on climate action in the normal. 2) providing the access to online platforms, it is the hope of ACCC that COVID-19 programs do nor further suppress movement-building and to further the right of CSOs and other stakeholders to participate in governance. 3) Supporting ACCC members gain access to inter--governmental platforms, regionally, other stakeholders and multi-lateral development banks and financial instiutions 4) ACCC will keep its commitment to the communities they work for to ensure alternative participatory and feedback mechanisms that inform the policy advocacy work.

title.narrative: COVID 19 and Flood Response in Bihar- 2020

description.narrative: By infusing cash into the local/mico economy, it will not only help address the immediate needs of these marginalized households but also boost the health of the local vendors and businesses.

To improve on our efforts to link beneficiaries to existing support systems, the project will identify the households that have the least coping capacity, are the worst affected due to COVID 19 and subsequently with floods this year in Bihar and in need of immediate support in the form of financial assistance and by helping the target community gain access to social security schemes. Subsequently, these households will be aided by us with the help of Unconditional Cash Transfers (UCT) that will help them cope and meet critical needs. Ground reports have suggested the provisional opening of local markets to serve the community, the project will engage the community and help them leverage this to their benefit.
